title: Is the sentence 'he slept a sound sleep' grammatically correct? - Quora

response.answer_text: It might be correct, but there are other alternatives. To describe or modify the noun “sleep” a qualifier is needed. this can be supplied with an Adverb which modifies sleep. I would communicate the idea this way, were I composing the sentence. “He slept soundly.” See the Interchange: Verb = to sleep Noun = “a sleep “ or “the sleep” (when the verb form and noun form are spelled the same, the part of speech is called a Heteronym. Example: Construct (verb) and Construct (noun, as in… “the construct” or “a construct”) We can always tell the difference between the verb and noun, by seeing if it is preceded by “a,” or “an,” or “the”. That shows us that a noun form is used. If there is no “the” or “a” or “an,” the heteronym is a verb. Adjective = sleepy Adverb = sleepily \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\ If you begin to study words with their Interchange Forms, you will find that you have greater freedom to express your ideas and feelings. Look for the Verb and see if it has a Noun Form, an Adjective Form, or an Adverb Form.

It’s grammatically correct, yes, but the use of the indefinite article weakens the description; if you’re going to use this, as a writer, you’ll do better to be more focused on the nature of that sound sleep, rather than leaving it to the reader to decide which of the possible ‘sound sleeps’ they should pick, given the indefinite article, ‘a’. Aim for a more specific ‘sound sleep’ — ‘he slept the sound sleep of a well-fed infant draped over the top of the family pet.’ Don’t leave it up to the reader to figure out which sound sleep the character was sleeping. Paint them the picture as you go; draw them into the scene, don’t make them do all the work. Best of luck!

Is the sentence "he slept a sound sleep" grammatically correct? Yes, it is. It will be even more correct if you use a capital ‘H’ for ‘he’ and a full stop at the end: He slept a sound sleep. It is unusual to use ‘sleep’ transitively, but it is by no means unknown. ‘He slept the sleep of the dead’ is a very common expression, meaning ‘He slept as deeply as if he were dead’. Your sentence is correct, and the alliteration with the three ‘s’s is pleasing to the ear. It may be poetic, it may be simply creative writing of some kind. It is FINE.

This is absolutely a grammatical sentence, and this kind of construction is attested constantly in English literature. It's true that “sleep” is usually an intransitive verb, so it's not clear whether this idiom (and others like it) is an exception to that -- or merely a fossilized form of some ancient Anglo-Saxon instrumental construction. Either way, yes, this is correct and even literary English.

Actually the grammar is wrong. SLEEP is an intransitive verb. You can’t sleep anything. Just like you cant SIT anything (the transitive verb is SET). You can’t LIE anything (transitive verb is LAY). No one says I slept a nap.
